subs.text: August 31

@joshuadtitus @ibogost Indeed. (As virtualization becomes more accessible to the non-tech user, development ~will~ become easier for vast majority of desktop applications.)

Internet-based services have an enduring edge in anything that requires real-time collaboration, frequent updates, or mobility.

@joshuadtitus @ibogost While listed ‚Äòoff the top of my head‚Äô, I included those specific ones due to personal knowledge of multiple people who ~currently~ use at least one of those nearly daily, by choice, at their homes or small businesses.

People use computers in sometimes vastly different ways.

subs.text: August 29

@joshuadtitus @ibogost E-mail: Eudora, then Mulberry for the IMAP generation

PIM and media: Palm Desktop and iTunes

Desktop publishing: Photoshop, Freehand, and Acrobat

SMB in-house apps and databases: FileMaker Pro and Visual FoxPro

Typing: Nisus Writer, WordPerfect 5.1 for DOS

subs.text:
@SarahEJoyal @timothyaclark @ibogost I was reading a design document from c. 1995 yesterday and a ‚Äòunified inbox‚Äô was all the rage back then (at the time, for: fax, e-mail, IM, voicemails, etc.).

BlackBerry tried again circa 2015 with their ‚ÄòHub‚Äô, but everyone generally wants to stay all siloed for profit reasons.

subs.text: Irony of the day, courtesy of @nngroup: Jakob Nielsen‚Äôs March 1999 #Alertbox article extolling #persistentURLs, ‚ÄúURL as UI‚Äù, is no longer accessible at its original URL ([link]). To be fair, it did work for over 20 years, which is ~much~ better than average!
subs.rawText:
Irony of the day, courtesy of @nngroup:

  Jakob Nielsen‚Äôs March 1999 #Alertbox article extolling #persistentURLs, ‚ÄúURL as UI‚Äù, is no longer accessible at its original URL (https://t.co/c4sm8YIhdd).

To be fair, it did work for over 20 years, which is ~much~ better than average!
